Row.Text: Protect to the End
Will try hard to clear Barbarian Camps. Likes civilizations that clear Barbarian Camps; dislikes civilizations that ignore Barbarian Camps.

Tomoe Udagawa, brave action is your primary strategy for upholding justice, and also your primary strategy for making friends. As the saying goes, "No discord, no concord"—the friendship that cuts through metal naturally requires quenching with gushing sincerity, and can withstand the test of unwelcome truth. Sincere bonds are like beloved ramen, bowl after bowl endlessly continued, each bowl offering a fresh taste, each bowl stacked strong as iron.
Soiya!

The drummer of Afterglow, a straightforward and strong-willed hardliner who enjoys helping others. Although she may seem a bit like a delinquent, she is actually quite kind-hearted; occasionally impulsive, she might scold out of love, but realizes her mistake the next moment and reflects/apologizes.

Very familiar with the adults in the shopping district, plays the wadaiko (Japanese drum) during festival events, and was selected as the representative of the shopping district's taiko team for the "Shopping District Youth Division". After entering her third year of high school, she started working part-time at Ginga Ramen with Masking and began studying for her motorcycle license.

Has a very good relationship with her younger sister Ako (good enough to bathe together), is her sister's idol, and is called the "world's strongest drummer" by her. As fellow older sisters, she can share experiences about being an elder sister with Sayo, who initially had a poor relationship with her own sister.

Loves ramen, especially tonkotsu shoyu ramen. Seems to have an encyclopedic knowledge of all the amazing ramen shops in the area, able to eat at a different one each time, each with its own unique wonders.
(Compiled from Moegirlpedia)

Wadaiko, as the name suggests, are large Japanese drums. Like gongs and drums in other countries, they are often used in festivals and grand events. In recent years, the arcade rhythm game "Taiko no Tatsujin" has also gained considerable popularity.

Tomoe Udagawa represents the shopping district's taiko team; her catchphrase "Soiya!" is the cheering sound heard at festivals where taiko teams perform. Additionally, Tomoe also plays the Taiko arcade game and is quite skilled (just barely losing to the conceptual goddess Mayi).
